awd_titl_txt: CRII: CPS: A Self-Learning Intelligent Control Framework for Networked Cyber-Physical Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to addresses challenges in machine learning for intelligent physical systems that interact with one another. The approach is to explore Reinforcement Learning (RL) strategies, where systems are rewarded when behaving correctly, for interacting physical systems when the systems with which they interact may react in inconsistent ways. The results are expected to contribute to a new self-learning intelligent control framework, where the systems under design can decide how to interact with their inconsistent neighbors in a way that will improve how they learn.  This will advance reinforcement learning for networked cyber-physical systems (CPS) which can have emergent behaviors when they interact (for example, unmanned aerial systems) and are frequently inconsistent due to uncertainties in their distributed nature (for example, the smart grid).

Three major fundamental contributions to the scientific field are expected. First, a new distributed RL algorithm will learn suitable reward functions automatically without requiring external supervisions. This work will relax human efforts and scale RL algorithms to more complex environment. Second, novel transfer learning-based RL architectures will be designed by reusing past knowledge from multiple sources. This design will further accelerate learning process in networked CPS. Third, this proposed method will be implemented on a multi-robot testbed to advance the learning in robot applications. Outreach and dissemination plans cultivate the scientific curiosity of K-12 students, and students from underrepresented groups, and motivate their interests in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM) programs. Furthermore, the integration of the project's cutting-edge research results into new courses will aid retention of current STEM students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
This CRII project focuses on developing a self-learning intelligent control framework to advance reinforcement learning (RL) approaches in networked cyber-physical systems (CPS) that adaptively learns suitable reward functions without external supervisions, automatically generalizes experience to new environment, and accelerates learning process while exploration. Specifically, the major contributions included the development of (1) intelligent control algorithms that facilitate the collaboration among networked agents to achieve goals that a single agent cannot accomplished, (2) transfer learning architectures to scale RL algorithms by reusing past knowledge from multiple sources, (3) self-learning design to ensure the learning when the optimal outside guidance is unavailable, (4) RL-based methods to improve learning and generalization capability for networked CPS in uncertain and stochastic environment, and (5) evaluation plans from theoretical analysis, algorithms evaluation and robotics testbed validation. As the networked control system has become one of the key technologies and economic development focuses across the world, this project provides novel insights for advancing and accelerating intelligent learning process for networked CPS.

This CRII project produced 2 journal papers and 7 conference proceedings. The research outcomes resulted in multiple awards and recognitions, including International Neural Network Society (INNS) Aharon Katzir Young Investigator Award (2021), Best Paper Award of IEEE Power & Energy Society (PES) General Meeting (2021), and Florida Atlantic University (FAU) College of Engineering & Computer Science Junior Faculty Research Award (2022). Furthermore, this CRII project created various educational training opportunities. Two Ph.D. students and six M.S. students (five of whom have graduated successfully with thesis defenses at the time of this report) are involved. The project has resulted in training undergraduate students through senior design projects (7 groups, 34 students), direct independent studies (2 female students), and undergraduate research projects (3 students, one of whom continuing his study as Ph.D. student under the supervision of the PI). Particularly, one senior design group has won People's Choice Award at the FAU Engineering showcase. The research results have also been disseminated to the broader community through various outreach activities, including the invited talk in FAU high school research seminar, invited talk in FAU S-STEM scholars meeting, and panelist of Diversity Faculty Sharing Experience Workshop in IEEE International Conference on Image Processing.

 


Last Modified: 05/12/2023
Modified by: Xiangnan Zhong
